column1: Following the [[The Lord of the Rings (1955 radio series)
column2: 1955 radio series]] of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', a [[wikipedia:Tooting
column3: Tooting]] resident named "Sam Gamgee" wrote to Tolkien on [[13 March
column5: March 18]], Tolkien replied. He explained his own origin of the name [[Gamgee Family
column6: Gamgee]], and mentioned the Gamgee family of [[Birmingham]]. In his letter, Gamgee had already shown awareness of his family's name fame in [[wikipedia:Sampson Gamgee
column7: the medical profession]]. Tolkien then asked for more information about the name, and offered a signed copy of ''The Lord of the Rings''.

column1: * In an editorial note, further correspondence is mentioned. Gamgee wrote back with family information, and accepted the gift kindly.

* In ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]'', pages 224-225, this episode was also mentioned. It was followed by: "[l]ater he said: 'For some time I lived in fear of receiving a letter signed ''S. Gollum''. That would have been more difficult to deal with." It was likely that this passage was from the fragment known as [[Letter 185]].
